div.p: PUT into one's MOUTH so as to SWALLOW.
1. The general word is shí 食 which refers to any form of taking in food, but the word is probably primarily a noun meaning "food". Cf. 飯疏食 "dine on coarse food".
2. Gān 甘 is to enjoy a meal or to enjoy food on a given occasion.
3. Rú 茹 is to eat a routine meal in order to still one's hunger.
4. Fú 服 ingest or imbibe for a purpose, typical a medical purpose.
5. Dàn 啖 is to eat quickly oneself and dàn 啗 is to cause someone to swallow.
6. Fàn 飯 is to dine on some basic foodstuff, and the word is secondarily a noun meaning "foodstuff, staple food".
7. Cháng 嘗 is to eat something for the purpose of experiencing the taste of it, rather than for the purpose of filling one's stomach.
8. Bǎo 飽 refers specifically to eating enough or having eaten enough and is most current as an intransitive verb.
9. Yàn 厭 / 饜 refers to eating more than enough is mostly used transitively.
10. Cān 餐 is a formal or poetic word referring to the eating of a desirable meal.
喫，唐宋後口語中的通稱。
咽，進食而下肚，側重在下。

note.p: EDERE alimentum solidum assumere. Qvod si fiat lente, dicitur Manducare, si avide rapaciter, Vorare; si lingva exserta, Lingere.

Thomas Kerchever Arnold, M.A. Rector of Lyndon, and late fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge

entry.def: Yàn 厭/饜 refers to eating more than enough is mostly used transitively.
Yàn 厭/饜 refers to eating more than enough is mostly used transitively.

sense.def: =饜 indulge oneself in; eat more of than is right; more than satisfy one's desires for eating and drinking to the full
get to savour, taste, appreciate the eating of 味甘味
taste by chewing and keeping in the mouth

entry.def: Dàn 啖 is to eat quickly oneself and dàn 啗 is to cause someone to swallow.
Dàn 啖 is to eat quickly oneself and dàn 啗 is to cause someone to swallow.
Cháng 嘗 is to eat something for the purpose of experiencing the taste of it, rather than for the purpose of filling one's stomach.
Cháng 嘗 is to eat something for the purpose of experiencing the taste of it, rather than for the purpose of filling one's stomach.

sense.def: TASTE> have as food, have to eat, take as food
put in one's mouth so as to eat; gulp down
take into one's mouth in order to eat
what is not eaten (on formal occasions)
eat the contextually determinate thing (on formal occasions)

entry.def: Fú 服 ingest or imbibe for a purpose, typical a medical purpose.

sense.def: eat or imbibe for a purpose
make the contextually determinate PIVOT eat N

entry.def: Gān 甘 is to enjoy a meal or to enjoy food on a given occasion.

sense.def: polite: eat the contextually determinate edible thing N

entry.def: Rú 茹 is to eat a routine meal in order to still one's hunger.

sense.def: SHI 260: take in, eat (typically something undistinguished)

entry.def: The general word is shí 食 which refers to any form of taking in food, but the word is probably primarily a noun meaning "food". Cf. 飯疏食 "dine on coarse food".

sense.def: act of eating; meal; time of a meal
feed on the contextually determinate kind of substances Nm
eat food, eat a meal; have a meal
feed on, eat (of animals); live on
allow N1 to live on/eat N2
to eat food characterised by N (e.g. taste)

entry.def: Fàn 飯 is to dine on some basic foodstuff, and the word is secondarily a noun meaning "foodstuff, staple food".

sense.def: eat a meal; eat one's meals
LIJI: dine on (certain dishes); eat from

簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Bǎo 飽 refers specifically to eating enough or having eaten enough and is most current as an intransitive verb.

sense.def: eat to one's heart's content; eat enough
take (unusual things, medicines etc.) as food
cause somebody to eat something; to feed somebody with something
get a proper meal, get to eat properly; get the best pieces of food
(of human subjects) eat a meal, have something (not necessarily anything distinguished) to eat, get something to eat, fill one's stomach

entry.def: Cān 餐 is a formal or poetic word referring to the eating of a desirable meal.

sense.def: cause someone to eat a regular meal> treat to a regular meal
enjoy the eating of (a meal, food and drink)

entry.def: Xiǎng 饗 refers to enjoying a festive meal, or in a transferred sense enjoying anything else in the way one might enjoy a festive meal. (NB: This is a different word and certainly not a variant character for xiǎng 享.)

sense.def: drinking and eating; consumption of drink and food
take a meal; eat and drink
eat up the contextually determinate object
eat from (a vessel) (XUN, for 餐, contested)
